dataset.title: Monthly Vegetation and Invertebrate Population Monitoring near the Georgia Coastal Ecosystems LTER Flux Tower

abstract.para: Permanent study plots were established in a Spartina alterniflora-dominated marsh in the vicinity of the Georgia Coastal Ecosystems LTER Flux Tower to provide measurements of plant biomass and invertebrate population density over time for comparison with marsh-atmospheric CO2 exchange. Six replicate plots were randomly placed within each of three height zones of Spartina alterniflora (i.e. short, medium and tall Spartina). Beginning in June 2013, surveys were conducted approximately monthly to determine abundance of Littoraria irrorata, Prokelisia marginata, and grasshoppers in each plot. Plant species, stem density, height, and flowering status were also measured in each of the plots, and biomass was calculated using allometric relationships between plant height, flowering status and mass from plant clipping studies. During these surveys, destructive core sampling was also performed in the proximity of the plots (n = 2 per zone) to measure above and below ground biomass for each Spartina zone. Beginning in February 2016, chlorophyll measurements were taken in the proximity of the plots in each Spartina zone (n = 15 per zone).

section.title: Permanent Plot Installation
section.para: Permanent plots were established in June 2013. Plots were randomonly placed in three zones across the marsh study site dominated by short, medium and tall form Spartina alterniflora (n = 6 plots per zone). The corners of plots were marked using PVC stakes to designate a 0.25m by 0.25m quadrat area in short and medium Spartina zones and 0.5m by 0.5m quadrat area in tall Spartina zones due to the larger size of individual plants.

section.title: RTK GPS Survey of Permanent Plot Locations
section.para: A survey was performed in February 2014 to measure the precise geographic locations and elevations of long-term plant plots at the GCE-LTER Flux Tower marsh near the Duplin River. The survey was performed using a Trimble R6 real-time kinematic GPS sytem with Global Navigation Satellite System (GLONASS) support. The base receiver was placed on a permanent cement base installed near each field site, connected to GLONASS satellite services via mobile 3G Internet connection, and allowed to establish a stable benchmark positional fix prior to the survey. A portable wireless rover unit was then used to collect and log horizontal position and vertical elevation data on the ground at the center of each plot. Data were then corrected and analyzed using Trimble Geomatics Office software to determine latitude, longitude and elevation, and plant plot locations were then registered in the GCE-LTER geographic database. Location, Longitude and Latitude columns were then added to the data table based on matching site, marsh zone and plot number of each record to the corresponding plot identifier in the geographic database.

section.title: Littoraria survey
section.para: A count of visible Littoraria irrorata snails (>5mm) was conducted using a 0.25m x 0.25m quadrat placed in the center of each 0.5m x 0.5m plot for the short and medium Spartina zone. In the tall Spartina zone snail surveys were conducted using a quadrat covering the entire 0.5m x 0.5m plot.

section.title: Grasshopper survey
section.para: Grasshopper abundance was estimated in a 2m x 2m area surrounding each quadrat by disturbing the Spartina with a PVC pole. Number of grasshoppers present was classified as absent, rare, common, or abundant.

section.title: Prokelisia survey
section.para: Abundance of Prokelisia marginata flies is estimated in each 0.5m x 0.5m plot and classified as absent, rare, common, abundant, or choking swarms.

section.title: Vegetation monitoring
section.para: Plant stems in each plot were measured (stem height and flowering status). Plants which were completely brown were not measured. A plant was recorded as flowering only when seedheads were present. A plant which has no seedheads remaining but still retains the stalk will has the stalk included in the height measurement.

section.title: Chlorophyll Measurement
section.para: We will take 15 Chlorophyll readings in each of the short, medium and tall Spartina zones using an Opti-Sciences CCM-200 chlorophyll meter, reading the first fully-expanded leaf from the top of the plant. Readings will be taken on plants that are at least 0.5 meter apart. Plants which are completely brown (senescent) will not be measured.

section.title: Core collection
section.para: Plant above:belowground biomass is monitored using destructive cores. Cores (n=2/zone) were collected in the same general area as the plots. Each core (4 inch diameter, 30 cm depth) was centered on a plant culm (2-4 stems). Aboveground live biomass was clipped and collected, then the core sample was collected. Cores were immediately sectioned into 0-10 cm and 10-30 cm depth increments

section.title: Laboratory analysis
section.para: In the laboratory, the cores were thoroughly washed to remove live roots and rhizomes from the sand/peat. Aboveground biomass was separated into green and brown leaves. Above and belowground biomass was dried at 60 degrees for 3 days and weighed. On some dates, dried material was shipped to the University of Georgia for further processing to determine carbohydrate content.

section.title: Flux Tower Veg
section.para: Permanent plots were established in short, medium and tall Spartina zones (n=6/zone). Plots measure 625 square centimeters (0.25m x 0.25m) for short and medium Spartina, and 2500 square centimeters (0.5m x 0.5m) for tall Spartina.

Surveys were conducted approximately monthly in permanent plots established in three Spartina alterniflora zones (short, medium, tall). Abundance of Littoraria irrorata, Prokelisia marginata, and grasshoppers was recorded in each of these plots. Vegetation species, stem heights, stem densities and flowering status were recorded for each plot as well. Core samples were taken in proximity of the plots to get biomass data for each Spartina zone. Chlorophyll measurements were made in each Spartain zone.

Two biomass cores (4" diameter, 30cm depth) were collected monthly in each Spartina zone, with the corer centered on a Spartina culm. Selected plants were chosen haphazardly within the short, medium, and tall zones.

project.title: Georgia Coastal Ecosystems LTER Project III

abstract.para: The Georgia Coastal Ecosystems (GCE) LTER is located along three adjacent sounds on the Atlantic coast and includes both intertidal marshes and estuaries. Long-term drivers of climate change, sea level rise and human alterations of the landscape will cause transitions in dominant habitat types (state changes) within the GCE domain by changing the amounts and patterns of water delivery across the landscape. These changes in water delivery can be conceptualized as presses and pulses in river inflow, local runoff, groundwater input, and tidal inundation, which will in turn manifest themselves as changes in salinity and inundation patterns in the domain. The research proposed for GCE-III is designed to address how variations in salinity and inundation, driven by climate change and anthropogenic factors, affect biotic and ecosystem responses at different spatial and temporal scales, and to predict the consequences of these changes for habitat provisioning and carbon (C) sequestration across the coastal landscape. The goals are to: 1) Track long-term changes in climate and human actions in the watershed and adjacent uplands, and evaluate the effects of these drivers on domain boundary conditions. 2) Describe temporal and spatial variability in physical, chemical, geological and biological, and to evaluate how they are affected by variations in river inflow and other boundary conditions. 3) Characterize the responses of three dominant habitats in the domain to pulses and presses in salinity and inundation. 4) Describe patterns of habitat provisioning and C sequestration and export in the GCE domain, and to evaluate how these might be affected by changes in salinity and inundation. These efforts will be synthesized into a synoptic understanding of both biotic and ecosystem responses to variations in salinity and inundation driven by climate change and human activities, which will be used to assess thresholds between habitats and the potential for state changes in the domain.

abstract.para: The GCE Data Toolbox is a comprehensive library of functions for metadata-based analysis quality control, transformation and management of ecological data sets. The toolbox is based on the GCE Data Structure, a MATLAB specification for storing tabular data along with all information required to interpret the data and generate formatted metadata (documentation). Metadata fields in the structure are queried by toolbox functions for all operations, allowing functions to process and format values appropriately based on the type of information they represent. This semantic processing approach supports highly automated and intelligent data analysis and ensures data set validity throughout all processing steps.

Quality control analysis was performed using the GCE Data Toolbox for MATLAB software. Column data types are validated upon importing the table into MATLAB, and qualifier flags are automatically generated for data values based on QA/QC criteria for each data column pre-defined in metadata templates (e.g. value range checks, sanity checks, pattern checks). Qualifier flags are also assigned to values that are imputed or derived, revised, or otherwise differ from values in the original data submission. A column of coded qualifier flags is generated and included in the data table if flags are assigned to any value in a data column.
